title: Double complex
summary: In mathematics, specifically Homological algebra, a double complex is a generalization of a chain complex where instead of having a Z {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} } -grading, the objects in the bicomplex have a Z × Z {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} \times \mathbb {Z} } -grading. The most general definition of a double complex, or a bicomplex, is given with objects in an additive category A {\displaystyle {\mathcal {A}}} . A bicomplex[1] is a sequence of objects C p , q ∈ Ob ( A ) {\displaystyle C_{p,q}\in {\text{Ob}}({\mathcal {A}})} with two differentials, the horizontal differential
